scenario_1.message: I’m thinking of raising the price on my handmade carpets because the cost of materials has gone up. But I don’t want to lose my regular customers.
Raising prices can protect your margins, but it might also alienate loyal buyers. Would you consider a small incremental increase or offering a bundled discount instead?
I’m worried that even a tiny hike will make people feel I’m exploiting them. If they leave, I’ll lose more in the long run.
You could frame it as a fair adjustment—explain the material costs and assure them of continued quality. Transparency often turns perceived loss into an accepted trade‑off.

scenario_2.message: My eldest son wants to learn how to weave, but I’m not sure if it’s worth investing time now when my business needs attention.
Teaching him can preserve your craft for future generations and may even open new revenue streams. What if you set aside a short weekly slot that also lets him practice the skills you value?
I’m afraid that taking time away from the shop could let competitors overtake us, especially with the new online market.

Consider integrating his learning into customer demonstrations—customers see skill development and may appreciate the authenticity. This way, training becomes part of your service offering rather than a loss.
